deck: Former Russian Cosmonaut and temporary Green Lantern of Kyle Rayner's "New Corps"
description:
Origin

A Lieutenant Colonel in the Soviet Air Force, Anya Savenlovich was chosen to be part of the top secret Project Helios. Launched into Earth orbit in 1964, the cosmonaut reported an explosion in the second stage rockets and would not be heard from again for the next thirty-five years. Adrift in space, Savenlovich and her capsule were frozen, keeping her alive for the intervening years. Traveling across the stars recruiting Green Lanterns to form a new Green Lantern Corps, Green Lantern Kyle Rayner had met up with alien bounty hunter Hammeroon. The alien's spaceship detected Savenlovich's distress signal and at Rayner's urging, the two rescued the cosmonaut. After she was thawed out, the news of her long hibernation came as quite a shock to her.

Anya was given a power ring and agreed to join with Rayner and others to form his new Corps, however, after a disastrous mission and a betrayal, Kyle decided to disband his self-proclaimed Corp, take back the rings and return to Earth. He would need more time and experience before he would be ready to recruit a new Green Lantern Corps. Learning from Rayner that the Soviet Union she knew was long gone, Anya Savenlovich chose to stay in space. She joined with Judge Sool and Garl Rathbone in creating an intergalactic crime fighting team known as "The Corps."

Creation

Anya was created by Chuck Dixon and Scot Eaton in the two part graphic novel "Green Lantern: The New Corps".

Character Evolution

Anya only appeared once more since the New Corps storyline in a splash page display within the Green Lantern Secret Files. She is depicted her alongside her crime fighting teammates "The Corps."

Major Story Arcs

Anya was a featured character in "Green Lantern: The New Corps".

Powers And Abilities

As a member of the Green Lantern Corps, she wields a green power ring with all the associated powers and limitations.
name: Anya Savenlovich

After several years in the Zone of Silence, Princess Sally and Sonic The Hedgehog find King Max, but sadly he had lost all memory of them both. King Acorn soon came to command a large army of goblin-like creatures and claimed the zone as his own and ruled it with an iron fist.

Later on, the Freedom Fighters find King Max once more and are able to rescue him from the Alien-like environment "Zone of Silence" and return him to Knothole village, unfortunately though he had been exposed to the harshness of the environment of the Zone of Silence for such a long time, his body soon began crystallizing. Than it was discovered that when the Sword of Acorn and the Crown of Acorn where brought together along with the King of Acorn it could make a magical healing ability. This was preformed and King Acorn was soon restored to his former self.

deck: Rhiahn is a member of The Mega-Monsters.
description:
Origin

There has been an on-going war between the Betans and Megans for centuries in which they have been using the services of war-monsters. The Megans had plans to conquer and plunder the planet Earth and unleashed three of their most powerful monsters called Rhiahn, Triax and Krollar. The monsters landed on the outskirts of Salt Lake City and battled Godzilla and Red Ronin. Rhiahn was a biomech monster that used his anterior bio-blade to decapitate Red Ronin. However, Rhiahn was defeated when Godzilla killed him with his own bio-blade.    

Creation

Rhiahn was created by Doug Moench and Herb Trimpe in 1978 and first appeared in Godzilla King of the Monsters # 12.   

Powers & Abilities

Rhiahn was a gigantic biomech monster which was a living creature with some parts of their bodies functioning like a machine. Rhiahn had a bio-anterior tale that he could spin so rapidly that it provided him flight and it also functioned as a powerful saw blade. Rhiahn had a clam shape head with a powerful bite and hook like hands to slash and tear. Rhiahn had superhuman strength, durability and resistance to injury.
name: Rhiahn

volume_credits.name: Essential Godzilla King of the Monsters

deck: Krollar is one of The Mega-Monsters.
description:
Origin

There has been an on-going war between the Betans and Megans for centuries in which they have been using the services of war-monsters. The Megans had plans to conquer and plunder the planet Earth and unleashed three of their most powerful monsters called Krollar, Triax and Rhiahn. The monsters landed on the outskirts of Salt Lake City and battled Godzilla and Red Ronin. Krollar could burrow underground and had a powerful suction mouth that consumed large chunks of land and property. However, Krollar was defeated when Godzilla burned him with his radioactive fire and smashed his body with a few stomps.  

Creation

Krollar was created by Doug Moench and Herb Trimpe in 1978 and first appeared in Godzilla King of the Monsters # 12.   

Powers & Abilities

Krollar was a gigantic biomech monster which was a living creature with some parts of their bodies functioning like a machine. Krollar had superhuman strength, durability and resistance to injury. Krollar had a biomech horn that he could retract at will and would use it to lock himself into the ground as he burrowed deep into the earth. Krollar had the capability of spitting out whatever he consumed with tremendous force as a range weapon.
name: Krollar

deck: Fictional editor of 2000AD.
description:
Tharg the Mighty is the fictional editor of 2000AD. He is from the planet Quaxxann but he works at the comics publishing office on Earth. Tharg also occasionally appears in his own stories or on the cover (usually written by the human editor at the time).

The Editors Behind Tharg the Mighty

  • Pat Mills (1977) Prog 1-16
  • Kelvin Gosnell (1977-1978) Prog 17-85
  • Steve MacManus (1978-1987) Prog 86-519
  • Richard Burton (1987-1993) Prog 520-872
  • Alan McKenzie (1993-1994) Prog 873-914
  • John Tomlinson (1994-1996) Prog 915-977
  • David Bishop (1996-2000) Prog 978-1199
  • Andy Diggle (2000-2002) Prog 1200-1273
  • Matt Smith (2002-Present) Prog 1274-Present

While the first Tharg (Mills) had the shortest time in the role, he has written for more progs than any of his successors (or any other writers for that matter). On the other side of the coin, the latest Tharg (Smith) has served the longest time in the role and is also the only one to have never written a comic in 2000AD (Burton wrote a three page story).

Other fictional British comic editors include:

  • Big E (Tornado)
  • Ghastly McNasty (Scream!)
  • Max the Computer (Eagle)
name: Tharg the Mighty

deck: A pivotal character in Kingdom Come; where Superman has come out of retirement and causes a schism between his generation and the newer amoral generation of superheroes.  As a normal man, he is chosen to bear witness to the possible end of the world.
description:
Origin

A humble pastor and preacher in the DC Universe, McCay inherits the prophetic dreaming abilities of Wesley Dodds (Sandman) and finds himself appointed by the Spectre (Jim Corrigan) to serve as his lost human conscience and help the Spirit of Vengeance to judge the forthcoming apocalyptic events in order to properly punish the guilty. Reluctantly, McCay serves as the Witness to the events of Kingdom Come.

Creation

Created by Alex Ross and Mark Waid. Norman McCay's visual appearance was actually based upon Kingdom Come's artist Alex Ross' actual father, Minister Clark Norman Ross.

History

In the otherdimension of Earth-22, Norman McCay is a deeply religious man who became a minister and in his later years, moved to Metropolis with his wife, Ellen to assume the role of the pastor of a small Presbyterian congregation which included Wesley Dodds, the long retired Golden Age Sandman.

Dodds is increasingly disturbed by the growing amorality and violence of the current generation of metahumans and discusses his fears with McCay and the two become close friends. Shortly after the death of McCay's wife, Dodds falls ill as well and has to be hospitalized himself.

Often visiting him in the hospital, McCay believed Dodds' ramblings of apocalyptic visions to be the result of senility or dementia. After Dodds' death, McCay finds that he is experiencing disturbing visions of his own. He is shocked to learn of the Kansas Disaster instigated by Magog who has replaced Superman as the dominant superhuman of this new and more violent age.

During a sermon, he begins screaming a warning of the coming apocalypse and upon recovering, is horrified that he has completely terrified his congregation.

In despair and wondering if he is losing his mind as well, McCay is approached by the Spectre (Jim Corrigan) who confirms that McCay has inherited Dodds' gift of prophetic dreams. After so many years, the ghostly Spirit of Vengeance has lost touch with his humanity and is unable to properly judge human beings anymore. He believes that he needs a human anchor to help him in his judgments and has selected McCay to serve in this role and to bear testament.

Together, McCay and the Spectre view the coming apocalypse as a pair of invisible witnesses; watching the reemergence of Superman and his reformation of the Justice League as well as the manipulations of Lex Luthor and his secret cabal who seek to destabilize the world in order to seize power for themselves.

Superman ultimately believes that they have no choice but to imprison the most violent superhuman offenders and constructs a monstrous Gulag and believes that they have finally begun to reassert control over the world.

McCay is abruptly dragged from the dimension from which he and the Spectre have been traveling through by the superhumanly swift Flash who is able to perceive the higher dimensions. Originally believed to be an intruder, McCay instead tries to warn Superman of the growing threat and the disaster about to befall them all. Superman however, dismisses him as a confused old man.

But McCay is proven right when a riot breaks out at the Gulag and Wonder Woman orders the other Leaguers to respond with lethal force, overriding Superman's protests. Desperate to save lives, Superman travels to the Batcave and tries to convince the infirm but still active Bruce Wayne to combine forces with him once more as the World's Finest Team to end this threat and they join the struggle. But the war between the metahumans has not gone undetected or unnoticed, and the United Nations decide to end the growing metahuman threat themselves by dropping a nuclear bomb on the Gulag, eliminating all of the metahumans; both hero and villain once and for all.

At this point, the Spectre asks who is the guilty party of this horrible event. Who is the one he should punish? McCay determines that there is no choice between any innocent or guilty parties or persons. There is no one person to be blamed for this horrible tragedy and this is much more complex than a simple struggle between good and evil. Satisfied, the Spectre allows the nuclear bombs to detonate.

Believing himself the only survivor, Superman is enraged by the massacre and he flies to the U.N. Headquarters and begins to bring down the entire building as punishment even as the Spectre is content to allow this to occur. Angrily, McCay demands the Spectre bring him to the U.N. to prevent more senseless loss of life. McCay chastises Superman, proclaiming that he has lost his way and his ability to empathize with humanity after his abandonment of his human identity of Clark Kent. This has all helped led them to this holocaust and helps calm Superman down and buying time for the other survivors of the nuclear detonation to reach the U.N.

Realizing that he is not the only survivor and that McCay is right, Superman promises to work with humanity rather than imposing their views and decisions. Satisfied, the Spectre brings McCay home and allows him to rejoin his life.

Norman McCay resumes preaching to his congregation a new message of hope for all of humanity. He is also frequently visited by the Spectre in his guise of Jim Corrigan who seeks to reconnect with his own lost humanity.

Powers & Abilities

Norman McCay possesses prophetic visions of future events. He had no conscious control of these visions and could not always control them or understand what these cryptic images represented. These visions could appear as flashes of future events or symbolic images. Unlike Wesley Dodds however, McCay does not need to be asleep to receive these visions.

Other Media

Print

Norman McCay also appears in a novelization of the Kingdom Come comic series of the same name. This novel was written by Elliot S! Maggin and has been printed as both a hardcover and paperback versions in 1998 and 1999 respectively.

Norman McCay's character and role in the story has not changed, although this novel greatly expands on McCay's background and also reveals that he was ordained as a Dutch Reformed Minister, a sect that was founded in the 16th Century in the Netherlands.

In this version, McCay also had the ability to "speak in tongues" during his visions and could also perceive ghosts and other spirits. He could also occasionally perceive events of the past as well and event the history of certain notable people.

deck: The Silver Streak was originally featured in Lev Gleason's Silver Streak Comics.  Currently he appears in Dynamite's Project Superpowers Universe.
description:
Golden Age
Not much is known about The Silver Streak, other then he was cab driver who was recruited by unnamed swami who owned a race car named "The Sliver Streak." Every driver of the car had been killed by giant insects. So the swami hypnotized the taxi driver into taking the job, only for him to be killed like the others .  This seems to have gotten the swami's goat worse than the others, because the swami used used his mystical powers to bring this particular driver back to life.  In his new life, the former driver had super speed and could fly, among other powers.

He later acquired a sidekick named Mercury and a pet falcon named Whiz who both gained similar powers by receiving blood transfusions from the Silver Streak.  He also briefly teamed with Daredevil against Adolf Hitler and the Claw. 

Project Superpowers
One of the heroes trapped in the Urn of Pandora, the Silver Streak first reappears in New Jersey where he helps 'Devil against the Claw organization.
name: The Silver Streak

description:
Creation

The original Scarecrow has many names but his real name is Christopher Syn. He is the subject of a series of novels. His first novel was called Doctor Syn: A Tale of Romney Marsh.

Character Evolution

The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen

Dr. Syn aka The Scarecrow who was well know and fear man by both sinner and saints alike, was a member of The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen along the woodsman know as Hawkeye, The Scarlet Pimpernel and his wife, Captain Gulliver during the 18th century.

Other Media

He appeared in three films including a Disney film decades ago. They are Doctor Syn (1937), Captain Clegg (1962), and The Scarecrow of Romney Marsh (1963). The third film The Scarecrow of Romney Marsh (1963) was a three part Disney mini series made for television.
